docs.snippet: The Enron Corporation said today that it had hired former Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and former Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher to help develop overseas projects.   Mr. Baker and Mr. Mosbacher have signed consulting agreements wit...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Enron Corporation said today that it had hired former Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and former Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher to help develop overseas projects. Mr. Baker and Mr. Mosbacher have signed consulting agreements with Enron, the nation's largest natural gas company, and will have an opportunity to invest in any projects they develop, the company said. Details of the agreements were not disclosed.

headline.main: Baker and Mosbacher Are Hired by Enron

docs.snippet: The Indian Government said yesterday that it had approved a $2.65 billion proposal from a United States group led by the Enron Corporation to set up a gas-fired power station in the western state of Maharashtra. Siddharth Behura, a senior Industry...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Indian Government said yesterday that it had approved a $2.65 billion proposal from a United States group led by the Enron Corporation to set up a gas-fired power station in the western state of Maharashtra. Siddharth Behura, a senior Industry Ministry official, said the proposal is the largest by a foreign company to be approved by India since the country began radical reform of its economy in July 1991.

headline.main: ENRON LEADS CONSORTIUM FOR POWER STATION IN INDIA

docs.snippet: The court ruled that in trying to increase competition in the power industry, national energy officials abdicated their responsibility to ensure fair electricity markets....
docs.lead_paragraph: The court ruled that in trying to increase competition in the power industry, national energy officials abdicated their responsibility to ensure fair electricity markets.

headline.main: Court Says U.S. Oversight of Power Industry Was Lax
headline.print_headline: Court Says U.S. Oversight Of Power Industry Was Lax

docs.snippet: Defense lawyers tried to sow seeds of doubt in the jury's mind about the damaging testimony that Ben F. Glisan Jr. gave against his former bosses....
docs.lead_paragraph: Under questioning by defense lawyers, Enron's former treasurer backed away on Thursday from statements that Jeffrey K. Skilling had supported a controversial off-the-books transaction as a way to skirt accounting rules, and admitted to other weaknesses in his earlier testimony. But Ben F. Glisan Jr., the last high-level manager expected to testify for the government in the criminal trial of Mr. Skilling, a former Enron chief executive, and the company's founder, Kenneth L. Lay, continued to insist that the Raptors financing vehicle he designed had no economic value. Instead, Mr. Glisan said, the Raptors was really an accounting artifice that won plaudits from Mr. Skilling and Mr. Lay for its ability to help Enron avoid reporting hundreds of millions of dollars in losses.

headline.main: Testimony On Enron Weakened A Day Later

docs.snippet: Enron's former chief accounting officer has reached an agreement with prosecutors to plead guilty to violating federal law....
docs.lead_paragraph: In a reversal that transforms the criminal case against Enron's former top officers, the company's former chief accounting officer has reached an agreement with prosecutors to plead guilty to violating federal law during his employment there, people briefed on the decision said yesterday. The former accounting officer, Richard A. Causey, had been viewed by lawyers in the case as likely to strike a plea deal with prosecutors and possibly serve as a witness for the government in the coming trial of two former chief executives of Enron, Kenneth L. Lay and Jeffrey K. Skilling.

headline.main: PLEA DEAL IS SEEN FOR ENRON FIGURE

docs.snippet: HOUSTON, July 13 (AP) - Federal prosecutors bought witnesses with immunity and then twisted facts to make their conspiracy and fraud case against five former executives of Enron's defunct broadband unit, lawyers for two of the defendants said on W...
docs.lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors bought witnesses with immunity and then twisted facts to make their conspiracy and fraud case against five former executives of Enron's defunct broadband unit, lawyers for two of the defendants said on Wednesday in closing arguments. ''They're on a hunt; they made up their minds,'' said Tony Canales, a lawyer for Scott Yeager, a former Enron Broadband Services strategist.

headline.main: Closing Arguments in Enron Broadband Case

docs.snippet: HOUSTON, May 12 (Reuters) - A federal judge on Thursday sentenced a former Enron finance executive, Daniel O. Boyle, to 3 years and 10 months in prison for his role in a fraudulent 1999 deal with Merrill Lynch & Company that helped bolster Enron's...
docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge on Thursday sentenced a former Enron finance executive, Daniel O. Boyle, to 3 years and 10 months in prison for his role in a fraudulent 1999 deal with Merrill Lynch & Company that helped bolster Enron's earnings. In addition, Judge Ewing Werlein Jr. of United States District Court sentenced the former Merrill Lynch bankers, Robert S. Furst and William Fuhs, to 37 months in prison each for fraud and conspiracy in the transaction.

docs.snippet: Lawyers for Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of the Enron Corporation, asked a federal court on Friday to separate his trial from that of his former boss, Kenneth L. Lay, on charges linked to the downfall of the energy company.     ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Lawyers for Jeffrey K. Skilling, the former chief executive of the Enron Corporation, asked a federal court on Friday to separate his trial from that of his former boss, Kenneth L. Lay, on charges linked to the downfall of the energy company. ''When parsed, the government's case against Lay is entirely separate from the case against Skilling,'' according to a motion filed in United States District Court by Mr. Skilling's lawyers, Daniel Petrocelli and Ron Woods.

headline.main: Ex-Chief of Enron Seeks Separate Trial

docs.snippet: Kenneth L. Lay, former chairman of the Enron Corporation, must wait until the end of September before a judge will decide whether to sever his fraud trial from those of other former officers of the company.       Mr. Lay asked Judge Sim Lake of Fe...
docs.lead_paragraph: Kenneth L. Lay, former chairman of the Enron Corporation, must wait until the end of September before a judge will decide whether to sever his fraud trial from those of other former officers of the company. Mr. Lay asked Judge Sim Lake of Federal District Court in Houston on Monday to sever his trial from that of the former chief executive, Jeffrey K. Skilling, and the former chief accounting officer, Richard A. Causey. Mr. Lay requested that the trial begin by Sept. 14.
docs.abstract: Federal Judge Sim Lake says he will not rule until end of September or October on Enron Corp former chairman Kenneth L Lay's request to sever his fraud trial from those of other former company officers (S)

headline.main: September Trial Is Rejected for Enron's Lay

docs.snippet: There was a time when Kenneth L. Lay's close relationship with President Bush brought him power and influence in Washington that was virtually unparalleled among his colleagues in corporate America.    Now, Mr. Lay, the former chairman and chief e...
docs.lead_paragraph: There was a time when Kenneth L. Lay's close relationship with President Bush brought him power and influence in Washington that was virtually unparalleled among his colleagues in corporate America. Now, Mr. Lay, the former chairman and chief executive of Enron, fears those ties may serve only to bring him criminal charges.
docs.abstract: Former Enron chairman and chief executive Kenneth L Lay discusses Enron's collapse, interview; says he did nothing criminal but accepts responsibility for debacle; notes his friendship with Pres Bush probably makes it harder not to bring criminal charges against him; blames collapse on wrong-headed and criminal acts of company's finance organization, specifically chief financial officer Andrew S Fastow; says Fastow misled him and board about activities and true nature of series of off-the-books partnership; defends some controversial moves, including some that set up conflicts of interest for Fastow; photos (M)

headline.main: Crimes of Others Wrecked Enron, Ex-Chief Says
